name: Game Play Analysis I
title: Game Play Analysis I
content:
Table: Activity

+--------------+---------+
| Column Name  | Type    |
+--------------+---------+
| player_id    | int     |
| device_id    | int     |
| event_date   | date    |
| games_played | int     |
+--------------+---------+
(player_id, event_date) is the primary key (combination of columns with unique values) of this table.
This table shows the activity of players of some games.
Each row is a record of a player who logged in and played a number of games (possibly 0) before logging out on someday using some device.

 

Write a solution to find the first login date for each player.

Return the result table in any order.

The result format is in the following example.

 

Example 1:

Input: 
Activity table:
+-----------+-----------+------------+--------------+
| player_id | device_id | event_date | games_played |
+-----------+-----------+------------+--------------+
| 1         | 2         | 2016-03-01 | 5            |
| 1         | 2         | 2016-05-02 | 6            |
| 2         | 3         | 2017-06-25 | 1            |
| 3         | 1         | 2016-03-02 | 0            |
| 3         | 4         | 2018-07-03 | 5            |
+-----------+-----------+------------+--------------+
Output: 
+-----------+-------------+
| player_id | first_login |
+-----------+-------------+
| 1         | 2016-03-01  |
| 2         | 2017-06-25  |
| 3         | 2016-03-02  |
+-----------+-------------+

mysql: Create table If Not Exists Activity (player_id int, device_id int, event_date date, games_played int)
mssql: Create table Activity (player_id int, device_id int, event_date date, games_played int)
oraclesql: Create table Activity (player_id int, device_id int, event_date date, games_played int)
metaData.name: game_analysis
postgresql: Create table If Not Exists Activity (player_id int, device_id int, event_date date, games_played int)

discussion_posts.name: tianshuhuang6
discussion_posts.content: `select player_id, min(event_date) as first_login from activity group by player_id`

discussion_posts.name: Bushi07
discussion_posts.content:
Would anyone be able to explain why the output gives date/timestamp?

select distinct player_id, min(event_date)
from activity 
group by player_id

Here is the output:

{"headers": ["PLAYER_ID", "MIN(EVENT_DATE)"], "values": [[1, "2016-03-01 00:00:00"], [2, "2017-06-25 00:00:00"], [3, "2016-03-02 00:00:00"]]}

discussion_posts.name: khaled_acmilan
discussion_posts.content: \tselect distinct player_id ,\n\t\t\t\t\tfirst_value(event_date) over (partition by player_id order by event_date) first_login\n\tfrom activity

discussion_posts.name: bdutko
discussion_posts.content:
for oracle, use TO_CHAR to convert timestamp to the YYYY-MM-DD format it wants. See below.

SELECT player_id as player_id, TO_CHAR(MIN(event_date),'YYYY-MM-DD') as first_login
FROM Activity
GROUP BY player_id

discussion_posts.name: edithi
discussion_posts.content:
You can use the groupby function in pandas to group the data by the 'player_id' column.
Within each group, you can use the min function to find the minimum 'event_date', which corresponds to the first login date for each player.
After obtaining the minimum login dates for each player, you can create a new DataFrame with the required columns and rename them accordingly.
Remember to pay attention to the column names, as they need to match the desired output format.

discussion_posts.name: davewang_2000
discussion_posts.content: Just wanna ask why most prefer to using window function with a subquery instead of using min() on discussion board?

discussion_posts.name: pritiprajapati314
discussion_posts.content: \tSELECT player_id, MIN(event_date) AS first_login\n\tFROM Activity\n\tGROUP BY player_id;
